questions.text: The spinal X-ray of a patient with chronic back pain is shown below. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the winking owl sign, which is seen in spinal metastases. It refers to the appearance of the spine when a pedicle is absent. 

The usual appearance of the pedicle representing two eyes on the AP projection is lost, as one pedicle is destroyed. It then appears like one eye is open and the other is winking or shut. Potentially, all bony metastasis can do this. However, breast cancer and lung cancer are commonly associated with this condition.

The 2 images given below show X-rays with a winking owl signs on different sides.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother, who was concerned that her daughter was shorter than her classmates. On examination, you notice that the girl has a webbed neck, shield-shaped chest and low posterior hairline. Suspecting a genetic disorder, you get a chest X-ray done. Which of the following signs will be seen on the X-ray?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest and low posterior hairline in the 10-year-old girl are highly suggestive of Turner's syndrome. The cardiovascular lesion associated with Turner's syndrome is coarctation of the aorta which shows the figure 3 sign on X-ray.

Figure 3 sign is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta and occurs due to indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre and post-stenotic dilatation along the left paramediastinum. 

Coarctation of aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation and Turner syndrome. It is more common in males.

On barium swallow, the reverse figure 3 sign (also known as the E sign) is seen as the medial equivalent of the figure 3 sign seen on chest X-ray. It is formed by prestenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta, indentation of the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

Notching of ribs (Roesler's sign) due to inferior rib erosion by dilated intercostal collateral vessels, is also seen in coarctation of aorta.

Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes (45 XO)- O for the absent X chromosome. Clinical features include short stature, short webbed neck, shield chest with widely spaced nipples, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies.

Two X chromosomes are required for the development of ovaries and the loss of one X chromosome results in streak ovaries with inadequate estrogen production. The loss of negative feedback from reduced estrogen raises the FSH and LH levels causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. 

Other options:

Option A: Egg-on-string sign is a characteristic X-ray finding seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA). It refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.

Option C: Snowman's heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Option D: Gooseneck sign is seen on left lateral angiograms in endocardial cushion defect. It is the most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given erect abdominal x-ray shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis.

The colon cut-off sign describes gaseous distension seen in the proximal colon associated with the narrowing of the splenic flexure. Though originally described in abdominal radiographs, this sign has also been demonstrated in contrast enema and computed tomography.

This appearance results from an inflammatory process extending from the pancreas into the phrenico-colic ligament via the transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure, resulting in the colon cut-off sign.

Other options:

Option A: Sentinel loop sign refers to the generalized or localized ileus of the intestine adjacent to the pancreas. A sentinel loop refers to a short segment of adynamic ileus adjacent to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. It is seen in acute pancreatitis.

Option C: Renal halo sign is produced by the apparent enhancement of the perirenal fat by an adjacent retroperitoneal exudate in the pararenal space. It is seen in acute pancreatitis.

Option D: Obliteration of the psoas shadow on imaging often indicates retroperitoneal pathology, such as infection, haemorrhage, or malignancy. It can suggest psoas abscess or inflammation in adjacent structures.

Related Pearl: X-Ray Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

 Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida has come for an antenatal ultrasound examination. The sonographic image appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the lemon sign, which is seen in spina bifida.

Spina bifida is the common open neural tube defect associated with hydrocephalus and Arnold-Chiari II malformation. It is the most common open neural tube disorder.

Spina bifida is characterized by a cleft in the vertebral column with a corresponding defect in the skin so that the meninges and spinal cord are exposed.

The lemon sign is related to changes in the configuration of the fetal frontal bone that loses convexity, becoming concave or linear at ultrasonography, and can be found during the first six months of gestation.

The banana sign is another sign that is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari II. There is herniation of the brainstem and cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, with the cerebellum surrounding the brainstem with a curved shape of a banana.

Other options:

Option B: Anencephaly is characterized by an open defect in the calvaria and skin, such that the cranial neural tube is exposed. It is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival. Frog eye sign is seen in USG. Prominent orbits (arrows) and an absence of cerebral tissue more cranially are seen.

Option C: Holoprosencephaly is a rare congenital brain malformation resulting from incomplete separation of the two hemispheres. On antenatal ultrasound there may be also evidence of polyhydramnios and ultrasound may also show a snake under the skull sign.

Option D: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of tuberculosis presents to the OPD with chronic cough, occasional hemoptysis, and persistent chest pain. A chest X-ray reveals a lesion, where the air inside shifts with changes in the patient’s position. What is the radiographic sign observed in this case?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray reveals a crescent-shaped radiolucent area surrounding a fungal ball, known as Monod's sign, commonly observed in aspergilloma within a pre-existing lung cavity.

Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity. 

Patients present with chronic features of fatigue, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, and wheezing. However, clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum and night sweats are more commonly observed in Tuberculosis which helps in differentiating the two conditions.

Chest X-ray shows a spherical or ovoid mass within a cavity. The mass is mobile. CT demonstrates a rounded mass within a cavity.

Images below show chest x-ray and CT findings in aspergilloma.

Other options:

Option A: Signet ring sign is seen in bronchiectasis where the internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery.

Option B: The "finger-in-glove" sign on chest X-ray or CT appears as a tubular, branching opacity, indicating bronchial obstruction with mucus impaction. It is commonly associated with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

Option D: The halo sign on chest CT appears as a ground-glass opacity surrounding a pulmonary nodule or mass. It is commonly seen in invasive aspergillosis and other angioinvasive infections.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female visits the OPD with complaints of irregular menstruation, with her last menstrual period being two months back. On per-speculum examination, you find a bluish hue of the vagina and vestibule. Which of the following signs may additionally be observed on per speculum examination?
questions.solution:
The patient with irregular menstruation and an LMP of 2 months back with a bluish hue in the vagina (Chadwick sign) is exhibiting signs of early pregnancy. Out of the given signs of pregnancy, Goodell's sign is a cervical change, i.e. softening of the cervix, which can be observed on per speculum examination. Hegar's, Piscaceks and Palmer's are uterine signs elicited by bimanual examination. 

The objective signs of early pregnancy in the cervix and uterus are:

questions.text: The following findings are noted when patient A attempts to make a fist and patient B tries to extend his fingers. What are the nerve injuries seen in patients A and B respectively?

choices.text: Proximal ulnar nerve, Distal median nerve
Distal median nerve, Proximal ulnar nerve
Proximal median nerve, Distal ulnar nerve
Distal ulnar nerve, Proximal median nerve

questions.solution:
In patient A, the hand's attitude while attempting to make a fist is called the Benediction hand sign and is seen in proximal median nerve injury. In patient B, a similar attitude seen at rest or while extending the fingers is called the partial claw hand and is seen in distal ulnar nerve injury. 

The 2 main muscles that are paralyzed in ulnar and median nerve injuries leading to characteristic hand deformities are the lumbricals and the flexor digitorum profundus. Distal nerve lesions affect only the lumbricals while proximal nerve injuries affect both muscles. This forms the basis of the different deformities of the hand seen.

The lumbricals are small muscles of the hand and are 4 in number. The function of the lumbricals is to flex metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints of 2nd–5th digits. The first and second lumbrical (lateral 2) are supplied by the median nerve while the third and fourth lumbrical (medial 2) are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

In the forearm, the flexor digitorum profundus is a flexor of the distal phalanges after the flexor digitorum superficialis has flexed the middle phalanges. It secondarily flexes the other joints of the fingers and the wrist. The medial half of this muscle is supplied by the ulnar nerve while the lateral half is supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve (branch of median nerve).

Ulnar nerve injuries:

Distal injury: Thus an injury to the distal ulnar nerve affects the 3rd and 4th lumbricals sparing the flexor digitorum profundus. This causes hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints, involving the ring and little fingers. This attitude of the hand known as the ulnar claw hand may be seen at rest and is more pronounced on attempting to extend the fingers as seen in patient B.

Proximal injury: Since the opposing flexor digitorum profundus of the 4th and 5th digit that causes the clawing is also affected, the clawing of the hand is less pronounced in distal injuries of the ulnar nerve. The deficits present during voluntary flexion of the digits. Thus, on attempting to make a fist, the flexion of the 4th and 5th digits is affected while the 2nd and 3rd digits are normal.

In both cases of ulnar nerve palsy, the sensory loss is confined to the medial one-third of the palm and the medial 1½ fingers including their nail beds. The medial half of the dorsum of the hand also shows sensory loss.

Median nerve injuries:

Distal injury: Thus an injury to the distal median nerve affects the 1st and 2nd lumbrical sparing the flexor digitorum profundus. This causes hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints, involving the index and middle fingers. This attitude of the hand known as the median claw hand may be seen at rest and is more pronounced on attempting to extend the fingers (attitude is similar to proximal ulnar injury).

Proximal injury: Since the opposing flexor digitorum profundus of the 2nd and 3rd digit that causes the clawing is also affected, the clawing of the hand is less pronounced in distal injuries of the ulnar nerve. The deficits present during voluntary flexion of the digits. Thus, on attempting to make a fist, the flexion of the 2nd and 3rd digits is affected while the 4th and 5th digits are normal giving the Benediction hand sign seen in patient A as shown below.

In both cases of median nerve palsy, there is loss of sensations on lateral 3½ digits including the nail beds and distal phalanges on the dorsum of the hand.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with chronic low-back ache underwent an oblique X-ray of the LS spine. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the X-ray given, there is a break in the region of pars interarticularlis of the L4 vertebra, which appears like a beheaded Scottish terrier sign. This is diagnostic of spondylolisthesis. 

Spondylolisthesis is the anterior displacement of a vertebra over another, usually at the lower lumbar spine. Occasionally, the displacement is backward (retrolisthesis). It is characterized by chronic back pain and lumbar lordosis. Normally, spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae can be palpated on the back smoothly. In spondylolisthesis, a step-off or step sign can be felt over the spinous process at the affected level.

The Beheaded Scottish terrier sign on the X-ray is diagnostic. It is due to a break in the pars interarticularis of the vertebra. The investigation of choice in the case of spondylolysis and spondylolisthesis is an oblique view X-ray of the lumbar spine.

Other options:

Option A: Normal spine: The posterior elements of the normal vertebra appear like a 'Scottish terrier dog' and this is known as Scottish terrier sign or Scottie dog sign (see image below).

Option C: In Spondylolysis there is a defect or break in the pars without dislocation. This gives the appearance of Scottish terrier with collar sign as shown in the image below.

Option D: Spinal tuberculosis occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region.

questions.text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile,pulse rate was 104 beats/min and there was right iliac fossa tenderness.The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following  signs is not seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The patient is diagnosed with acute appendicitis based on the clinical presentation and a CT scan revealing an appendix measuring more than 6 mm. Ballance's sign is not associated with appendicitis but is observed in cases of a ruptured spleen.

Ballance sign is positive if there is a fixed dullness to percussion in the left flank and shifting dullness to percussion in the right flank. The fixed dullness is  due to the presence of coagulated blood near the lacerated spleen while the shifting dullness is due to the presence of blood in the peritoneal cavity.

CT signs of appendicitis include an appendix measuring greater than 6 mm in diameter, appendicolith and enhancement of its wall with intravenous contrast medium  Surrounding inflammatory changes include increased fat attenuation, fluid, phlegmon, caecal thickening, abscess and extraluminal gas.

Other options:

Option A: Aaron sign is pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to Mcburney point.

Option B: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may cause pain in the right iliac fossa.

Option C: The Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Occasionally, an inﬂamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip ﬂexed, for pain relief.

Note: CT axial cuts are viewed from below to top and thus appendix is on the left of the CT image.

questions.text: Sonographic evaluation of a 26-year-old woman, who presented with complaints of amenorrhea for 12 weeks revealed the twin gestation as shown in the image below.  The type of gestation seen here is which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

If the division of the inner cell mass occurs within 3 days, it results in dichorionic diamniotic twins (DCDA)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

Twinning and Time of division:

4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

Note: "T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding.
questions.solution:
The image shows Battle's sign.

It is retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone. 

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk of intracranial placement. Noninvasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) is avoided due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

Other options:

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

Option C: Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa lining the mastoid air cells to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system. Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness and swelling which is painful. 

The image below shows a smooth ironed-out mastoid with erythema seen in acute mastoiditis.

Option D: The Griesinger's sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis.

questions.text:
A elderly hypertensive man presented with unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech. NCCT scan was done to reveal the following sign. What is the name of the sign?

NCCT - Non-contrast computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech in a hypertensive man is suggestive of stroke. The NCCT image is showing hyperdense MCA sign i.e. occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA) due to a hyperdense embolus. This sign is indicative of ischemic stroke. 

After the clinical diagnosis of stroke is made, an emergency evaluation should be made to check patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs), hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia. The main goal is to distinguish it as either an ischemic stroke or hemorrhagic stroke with the help of an emergency noncontrast head CT. 

The following signs of acute ischemia can be seen on CT:

  • Blurring of the gray/white junction and effacement of the sulci due to ischemic swelling of the tissues.
  • Blurring of the margins of the gray matter structures
  • In cases of internal carotid artery occlusion or middle cerebral artery main segment (M1) occlusion, intraluminal clot may be seen as a focal hyperdensity, known as the hyperdense MCA sign or hyperdense dot sign.

Management includes:

  • Reduction of blood pressure when: BP >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.
  • Serum glucose maintained between 60 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL.
  • IV mannitol and water restriction may be required to reduce edema which can lead to a mass effect.
  • Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (0.9 mg/kg), tenecteplase (0.25 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).
  • Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.
  • Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 300 mg should be started within 48 hours of acute ischemic stroke.

Other options:

Option A: String sign of Kantor is seen in Crohn's disease. It refers to the string like appearance of a contrast filled bowel loop due to luminal narrowing.

Option B: Eye of tiger sign is seen due to T2 hypointensity in the globus pallidus with a longitudinal stripe of high intensity. It is commonly seen in pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) but is not pathognomic of the condition. It can be seen in Wilson's disease, atypical parkinsonism and organophosphate poisoning.

Option D: The dural tail sign is seen in meningioma due to thickening and enhancement of dura.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is this finding characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows a confluent macular violaceous erythema called the V sign seen in patients with dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune disorder affecting, predominantly, the skin and skeletal muscle and usually presents initially with a facial rash, especially around eyelids, which can be pruritic and sore. Myositis symptoms are usually weakness and fatigue especially while climbing stairs, raising arms, and standing from sitting due to proximal muscle weakness. The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

The clinical signs seen in dermatomyositis are as follows:

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron papules - flat-topped lichenoid eruption on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joint.
  • Shawl sign or V sign - fixed erythematous macular erythema.
  • Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold.
  • Proximal myopathy.
  • Poikiloderma atrophicans vascular.
  • Calcinosis cutis.

Anti‐Jo‐1 antibody is commonly associated with this condition. Serum creatinine kinase levels are elevated in the majority of the patients. Management includes systemic corticosteroids which are usually effective.  

The cutaneous signs of dermatomyositis are given in the image below.

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: This is the radiograph of a child with a foreign body in the oesophagus. What is the sign seen in this?
questions.solution:
The presence of a halo sign or double ring sign is indicative of the foreign body being a button battery.

Button batteries and sharp objects in the oesophagus and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms all mandate urgent endoscopic removal.

Button batteries, in particular, are very dangerous foreign bodies, which must be expediently removed because they can cause:

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the oesophagus in 4 hours

Injury is thought to be secondary to electrochemical burns from electrical discharge. Chemical burns from electrolyte alkali leakage and pressure necrosis also may contribute to mucosal injury.

Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the oesophagus can be observed for up to 24 hr in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

Another AP and lateral X-ray demonstrating the presence of a button battery in the oesophagus is as shown below.

Other options

Option A: Thumb sign is seen in acute epiglottitis.

Option B: A steeple sign is seen in croup or laryngotracheobronchitis.

Option D: String sign on the barium enema is in ileocecal tuberculosis.

questions.text: A  patient comes with a history of difficulty in closing his eyes for the past 1 month. On examination, you note lid retraction in the right eye as shown below. What did you note on examination?
questions.solution:
The examination finding and image show Dalrymple's sign.

It is the commonest and earliest sign of Grave's ophthalmopathy. Here there is lid retraction and scleral show. The scleral show occurs due to the lid margin being level with or above the superior limbus, causing the upper sclera to become visible. The cause of lid retraction is thought to be the overactivity of levator aponeurosis and Müller muscle.

Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in hyperthyroidism. In this condition, autoantibodies bind to thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors and stimulate the secretion of thyroid hormone. 

Thyroid ophthalmopathy or thyroid eye disease can be seen in Graves disease or even in euthyroid/hypothyroid patients. Women and smokers are at higher risk of developing Grave's ophthalmopathy (otherwise known as thyroid eye disease). 

Thyroid function tests and a thyroid autoantibody assay should be done to assess thyroid hormone status. 

Control of hyperthyroidism is effective in management. Injecting botulinum toxin to levator aponeurosis and Müller muscle may be done as a temporary measure.

The other options are all signs associated with Grave's disease but do not correlate with the given image.

questions.text: While examining a stroke patient with UMN signs, the clinician performed the test given below and elicited a sign, which is equivalent to the babinski sign. Which is the sign elicited by the clinician?
questions.solution:
The sign elicited by the clinician which is equivalent to the Babinski sign is Hoffman’s sign.

To carry out this reflex after positioning your right index finger beneath the patient's middle finger's distal interphalangeal joint, apply a sudden downward flick to the nail. Check for any thumb reflex flexion in the patient.

Other options:

Option B: Bastian Burns sign is the loss of tone and deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs with preserved sensation in the presence of complete transection of the spinal cord above the level of conus medullaris.

Option C: Wartenberg sign refers to the involuntary abduction of the fifth finger due to ulnar nerve palsy, often seen in cases of ulnar neuropathy, 

Option D: Clasp knife sign is characterized by initial resistance to passive movement of a spastic limb, followed by a sudden release, commonly seen in upper motor neuron lesions due to corticospinal tract damage.

questions.text: A patient was brought dead to the casualty. Fundoscopy exhibits the sign as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most accurate inference regarding the time of death?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows the Kevorkian sign. Hence, the most accurate time of death is less than 1 hour.

Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels and lasts for about 1 hour. This means that the patient had died within the preceding hour. 

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels and occurs due to loss of blood pressure. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized using an ophthalmoscope.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea: Dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled.
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death.
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous:  Linear increase up to 100 hours following death.
  • Tache noir: One of the post-mortem ocular signs. A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with the base towards the margin of the cornea and the apex towards the medial or lateral canthus of the eye which becomes brown and then black. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with a glomus tumor and on otoscopy you see the following image. Which of the following sign is seen here?
questions.solution:
The rising sun sign is seen here, as it is a case of a glomus tumour. The rising sun appearance is seen when a tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear. 

Glomus tumours are the most common benign tumours of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IXth cranial nerve. 

Signs seen in intratympanic glomus tumour are -

  • A rising sun sign when a tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear.
  • Pulsation or Brown sign: when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum, the tumour pulsates and blanches, this reverses when pressure is released.

Other presentations of glomus tumour include bleeding polyp if the tympanic membrane is breached, and pressure symptoms causing cranial nerve palsies. These are -

  • Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate, due to IX and X nerve.
  • Vocal cord paralysis due to X nerve.
  • Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles - XI nerve.
  • Atrophy of half of the tongue - XII nerve.

They are diagnosed by CT scan, MRI, and four-vessel angiography mainly. It is treated by surgery, radiation, embolization, or a combination of them. 

Other options:

Option A: Cartwheel appearance is the leash of blood vessels that appear along the handle of the malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane.

Option B: Lighthouse sign is a pulsatile discharge from a pin-hole perforation of pars tensa seen in mastoiditis. 

Option D: Schwartze sign is the reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane in otosclerosis.

questions.text: Amsler sign is seen in _______.
questions.solution:
Amsler sign is seen in Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI).

Amsler sign is the hemorrhage caused by cataract surgery in FHI. During cataract surgery, fine filiform hemorrhages from the opposite angle are seen to occur as soon as the anterior chamber is opened. This is due to neovascularization.

Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidiously progressive, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. Stellate keratic precipitates (KPs) are seen and tiny crystals (Russell bodies) may be present on the iris surface. There are no posterior synechiae. Rubeosis iridis may be present. 

Features of Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis:

  • Insidious
  • Non-granulomatous
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Unilateral
  • Stellate keratic precipitates (KPs)
  • Tiny crystals (Russell bodies) may be present on the iris surface
  • Absence of posterior synechiae
  • Rubeosis iridis

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought by his parents with the following lesions for one week. On examination, Darier's sign is positive. Lesions are not seen in the palms, soles and face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient with positive Darier's sign and reddish‐brown maculopapular lesions on the trunk is urticaria pigmentosa. 

Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. The symptoms occur due to the release of mast cell-derived mediators. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20–40 years in the adult type.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in a symmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. Even though the neck and the hairline can be affected, the face is usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other features :

  • Flushing
  • Pruritus
  • Heat or cold intolerance
  • Recurrent diarrhea
  • Dyspepsia
  • Depression
  • Headache

Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. Darier's sign is not specific to mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.


Treatment of urticaria pigmentosa includes: 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • PUVA (Psoralen + ultraviolet light A) therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib.

Other options:

Option A: Café‐au‐lait macules (CALMs), also called Café‐au‐lait spots, present as well-circumscribed, hyperpigmented, light brown to dark brown macules and patches that range in size. They may appear at birth or in the first decade. They may be present on any body part, but most commonly involve the trunk and the extremities. They are associated with several genetic syndromes such as neurofibromatosis (NF1).

The image below shows Café‐au‐lait spots:


Option B: Tinea corporis is fungal infection of glabrous skin. It includes lesions of the trunk and limbs, excluding ringworms of specialized sites such as the scalp, feet, and groins. Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. 

The image below shows itchy,pink-to-red, round patches with raised scaly borders that tend to be clear in the center of tinea corporis:


Option D: Chronic bullous dermatosis (linear Ig A Dermatosis) of childhood is an autoimmune blistering disease in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as Linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid.

It presents as tense blisters and vesicles urticated plaques with erythema. They are arranged annularly in a “crown of jewels” formation. Varying degrees of pruritis may be present. The most common sites are the perioral area and perineum, followed by the trunk and limbs.
